passages.text: August 29, 2025 06:30 AM GMT
Housing Fixtures | Japan
Continue to Focus on Undervalued Rinnai

Focus strong on overseas as growth market (US, China, Europe) but demand remains weak. Subindustry unlikely to be favored on macro top- down basis, but harsh environment priced in; attention on undervalued stocks with profit expansion potential.
Existing home demand remains weak in US, while demand is weak for new and existing homes in China, and weak trends continue in Europe.
In Japan, renovation is strong but new build demand is weak.
Stock selection: Order of preference: Rinnai (OW) > Sanwa Holdings (EW) > LIXIL (EW) > TOTO (EW) > Noritz (UW). Key points below.

Rinnai: Domestic recall response to affect earnings in short term, but in mid- term we still expect strong earnings centered on Japan. Future earnings not priced in to stock; looks undervalued. Domestic recall impact to normalize from 3Q; also focus on fixed cost controls (cost cuts) in domestic profit for F3/26. In China, demand has been weaker than expected, mainly due to the sluggish real estate market, leading to a more conservative profit outlook. However, there has been no change in the positive impact from cost- saving measures such as workforce adjustments and expense reductions, as well as steady growth in sales of modular products.

Sanwa Holdings: Expect strong earnings, especially in the Americas and Japan, but due to ongoing weak demand for US non- residential, expectations for strong earnings (consensus overshoot) driven by the Americas are getting harder to uphold. In the short term we think the P/E ratio will not rise as it has in the past.

LIXIL: High dividend yield, remains a key point of interest. While Grohe is performing better than expected, ASB continues to underperform. With limited upside in the P/ E ratio and few positive catalysts, the stock lacks strong buying appeal.

TOTO: Earnings in new business areas remain solid, but core domestic housing equipment segment sluggish due to weak remodeling demand and rising external procurement costs. The anticipated V- shaped recovery in OP from structural reforms in China is expected in F3/27, as the benefits will take time to materialize. As a result, it may be difficult for overall consolidated profit expectations to rise. Additionally, concerns remain over the impact of US tariffs, leaving few short- term buying catalysts.
Noritz: Dividend yield low compared to LIXIL. Current environment continues to make the company less favorable from earnings/dividend yield perspectives.
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD.
Ryo Yagi Equity Analyst

We lower our OP estimate for F3/26 from \(\) 22.5bn\(to\) \ \(21.3bn\) (- 2.7% YoY) and pitch our estimate for F3/27 at \(\) 21.8bn\((+2.3\% YoY). This is mainly due to (a) reduction in our sales assumptions to reflect weaker remodeling demand than we previously envisaged and (b) sharper increases than we expected in external procurement costs (plastic, electronic components, etc.) and in expenses such as investment in human resources.
We nudge up our OP estimates, mainly to reflect uplift to our expectations for Asia,

OP: We make no change to our OP estimates, still expecting a loss of \(8.0bn\) in F3/26 ( \(3.55bn\) loss in F3/25; guidance: \(8.0bn\) loss) and a loss of \(1.0bn\) in F3/27. We thus expect the loss to narrow sharply in F3/27 mainly as a result of measures to optimize the human resources system implemented in F3/26 and the dropout of the loss due to production cuts booked in F3/26.

Human resource system optimization: The firm is implementing restructuring measures in F3/26, suspending production at the Beijing and Huadong plants in April. Agreements with employees for redundancy or transfer to other bases resulting from the liquidation of the two plants have been finalized. Management expects the closures to deliver an annual fixed cost saving of around \(7bn\) (reduction in labor costs, etc.). This is expected progressively to boost earnings from 3Q on and to make a full year's contribution to earnings in F3/27 (with the move expected to contribute from F3/26 2H, it will basically make a half year's contribution to full- F3/26 earnings).

Production cut losses: The company is scaling back production from F3/26 2Q to adjust inventory levels and the cut to production is planned to be reversed by the end of the year (China's 4Q). Therefore, the loss due to production cuts should drop out in F3/27.

We expect these factors to dramatically reduce the size of the operating loss in F3/27 although we expect the China business to remain in the red (the company envisages a swing to the black in F3/27). This is because both project and retail demand continue weak.

On a local currency basis, sales contracted 31% YoY in F3/26 1Q (Jan- Mar 2025). They are expected to contract 26% in 2Q, as the market remains weak and the competitive landscape harshens. The company intends to launch new mid- range products as planned. Since we are doubtful as to whether this will drive a meaningful improvement in sales, we pitch our F3/27 OP estimate conservatively, on the assumption that demand will remain weak.

OP: Our OP estimates remain unchanged at \(6.0bn\) in F3/26 (+16.4% YoY: guidance: \(6.5bn\) ) and \(6.4bn\) in F3/27 (+6.7% YoY). Initial F3/26 guidance reflects the level of US tariffs in force at the time of the Apr 28 F3/25 results release (uniform 10ppt increase in tariffs on imports from China and Mexico). At the 1Q results release, the company shared its recalculation of tariff impact based on the level of tariffs agreed through negotiations by Jul 31 (Vietnam, etc.), concluding that there is minimal change from the impact announced at the Apr 28 results briefing (it plans to offset the impact of the tariff on imports from Vietnam by handing it on in product prices). However, we remain concerned about the potential impact of US tariffs on earnings due to concern about the impact of high tariffs on imports from Asian countries other than Vietnam (Malaysia, etc.) and the possibility that price hikes implemented to offset tariff impact will undermine demand, and will continue to monitor the situation closely.

The company manufactures roughly half of its sanitaryware for the US market in Vietnam, with one- quarter imported from Mexico and the remaining quarter manufactured elsewhere in the Americas. The majority of Washlet products are imported from Malaysia while faucet fittings are imported from Vietnam.

US Georgia plant expansion: The shares rose sharply on Aug 25 after the Nikkei newspaper reported on Aug 22 that the company announced expansion of its sanitaryware plant in the US state of Georgia, increasing its production capacity by half from the autumn. However, this does not constitute a new development, as the plant expansion was completed in November 2024 in a bid to achieve the US sales growth called for by the medium- term management plan. Moreover, while the company plans progressively to increase the weighting of production in the US, we cannot expect a swift rise in the percentage of sanitaryware manufactured in the Americas from the current roughly \(25\%\) level (it will rise gradually), meaning that the impact of the tariff on Vietnamese imports is unlikely to disappear near term. Furthermore, there is still concern about the impact of tariffs on Washlet products, as the majority will continue to be imported from Asia.

We raise our OP forecast slightly, mainly to factor in uplift to our OPM assumption to reflect healthy plant capacity utilization. We increase our estimate for F3/26 from $8.7bn to $8.8bn (+6.8% YoY: guidance: $8.7bn) and for F3/27 from $8.8bn to $9.1bn (+3.4% YoY).

We raise our OP forecast, lifting our estimate for F3/26 from $24.9bn to $26.0bn (+27.3% YoY; guidance: $26.5bn) and for F3/27 from $25.3bn to $26.0bn (flat YoY). This mainly reflects an increase to our sales forecast backed by stronger demand for both new and replacement products than we had envisaged. The uplift to our F3/26 estimate also reflects an increase to our OPM assumption, thanks to a bigger contribution from gains on higher capacity utilization than we previously looked for.

1) V-shape OP recovery via China restructuring not expected until F3/27 as restructuring effects take time to materialize. 
2) Residual concern for US tariff effects on earnings due to possible effects of high levies on Asian countries outside of Vietnam (Malaysia, Thailand, etc), and demand hit from associated price increases. 
3) Little sense of undervaluation, little to fuel investment in the near term. New domains are healthy but core domestic housing fixtures are being held back by subdued remodeling business, rising costs for outsourcing, etc. Little currently to lift the overall consolidated profit trajectory.

We lower our OP estimates for F3/26 and F3/27, mainly due to reductions to our estimates for the North America and Europe segments, dropping our estimate for F3/26 from \(85bn to\) 84bn (+4.3% YoY; guidance: \(81bn) and for F3/27 from\) 90bn to \(89.5bn (+6.5\% YoY).\)

Our OP forecast for the Japan segment remains unchanged. 1Q OP came in lower than we expected due to a shortfall in sales versus our estimate. However, this was mainly due to the impact of progress on work in hand. Accordingly, we make no change to our forecast for F3/26 on and continue to forecast a guidance beat this fiscal year, as (1) demand remains firm and orders solid and (2) margins at the order stage are healthy.

(2) North America: We lower our OP forecast, mainly due to a reduction in our sales estimates, cutting our estimate for F3/26 from ¥44bn to ¥43bn (+3.6% YoY; guidance: ¥40.4bn) and for F3/27 from ¥47.5bn to ¥46.8bn (+8.8% YoY). We are now taking a more conservative view on sales due to weaker demand than we previously envisaged, mainly in the non-residential market.

On a local currency basis, 1Q sales inched down 0.4% YoY. While a rise in market share made a positive contribution to sales, weak demand resulted in a loss of volume. Nonresidential demand in particular is weak.

1Q non- residential sales were impacted by a wait- and- see mood ahead of President Trump's announcement of his tariff policy. Sentiment among customers placing orders with Sanwa has improved in 2Q, which should drive a QoQ improvement in sales. Nevertheless, we are now more cautious about the future outlook for both residential and non- residential demand than we were before.

Non- residential demand weakness owes to weak warehouse and plant demand. We believe weakness in warehouse demand may be due to a reduction in project starts as a result of rising construction costs as well as the peaking of construction demand. The current weakness of plant demand could be due to timing issues for individual projects so we will seek to ascertain the level of demand ahead. Longer term, the Trump administration's policy of using tariffs to promote the reshoring of manufacturing could provide a tailwind for Sanwa's earnings, and we will be keeping a close eye on developments here.
While residential demand is not as anaemic as non- residential demand, we think that elevated mortgage interest rates make a substantial recovery in demand unlikely.

Market share expansion: Sanwa's market share showed a further steady rise in 1Q. This was thanks to the following two factors. (i) Recovery in the share of supply to existing customers, which had fallen as a result of parts shortages caused by supply chain disruption from mid- 2022 through mid- 2023. Amid supply chain normalization, the quality of Sanwa's products is driving improvement in this market share. (ii) The capture of market share for new customers.

Price trends and tariff impact: Price reductions in F3/26 1Q shaved 1.3% from OP. However, the company has announced a 5% price increase in order to hand on tariff impact. This should start to contribute from 2Q and we expect product prices to make a positive contribution to profit from that quarter on.

OP: Although we have lowered our OP forecast, we still expect a guidance beat, as an earnings boost from cost cutbacks through plant reorganization is steadily materializing; steel prices are tracking lower than the company envisaged; and the yen is weaker than guidance assumes.

(3) Europe: We lower our OP forecast mainly to reflect a reduction in our sales estimates (local currency basis), reducing our OP estimate for F3/26 from ¥3.5bn to ¥3.2bn (-6.0% YoY; guidance: ¥4.1bn) and for F3/27 from ¥3.6bn to ¥3.3bn (+3.1% YoY). This factors in a bigger drop in plant capacity utilization than we previously anticipated in the face of weak demand.
Demand is picking up in the UK but remains weak in Germany and elsewhere. Overall,
both residential and non- residential demand remains downbeat in Europe.

Still expect firm earnings centered on Americas & Japan, but not undervalued

We still see earnings remaining firm centered on Americas/Japan but think healthy earnings are among factors that are priced in to an extent and that the stock is not undervalued. 1Q OP missed consensus due partly to subdued Americas business, hit by soft demand especially in non- housing. This reflected wait- and- see ahead of President Trump's tariff policy announcement so we expect a positive QoQ contribution in 2Q given an improving stance among users. But demand, esp. non- housing, remains generally subdued and we think Americas firmness is less likely than before to fuel high expectations of healthy (above- consensus) earnings. For now we think P/E is unlikely to rise above existing levels.

We hike our business profit forecasts from \(\yen 37bn\) to \(\yen 41bn\) \((+30.8\%YoY;\) guidance: \(\yen 35bn\) for F3/26 and from \(\yen 47.5bn\) to \(\yen 52bn\) \((+26.8\%)\) for F3/27 mainly due to raising our estimates for LWT (Japan and International) and LHT (Japan).

(1) LWT: We raise our BP forecasts from \(\yen 40.5bn\) to \(\yen 44bn\) \((+19.2\%YoY;\) guidance: \(\yen 40.5bn\) for F3/26 and from \(\yen 49.5bn\) to \(\yen 53bn\) \((+20.5\%)\) for F3/27) mainly due to hiking our forecasts for the International business. In F3/26, we think profit gains at Grohe will drive profit growth. In F3/27, we expect the main drivers to be loss contraction at ASB and again profit gains at Grohe.

American Standard brand: We lower our BP forecasts after cutting our sales forecasts to reflect weak demand. In F3/26, we also factor in an impact from the transition to a new ERP system (impacted in IQ). Consumer demand remains weak, with no signs as yet of the situation improving.

We expect ASB to record business losses of \(\yen 47mn\) ( \(\yen 44mn\) YoY; previous forecast: \(\yen 26mn\) in F3/26 and \(\yen 11mn\) (prev. \(\yen 0\) ) in F3/27, before breaking even in F3/28 (prev. \(\yen 7mn\) ).

While we assume losses will shrink in F3/27 thanks to benefits from the sale of the bath business (reduced fixed costs), higher sales, and the drop- out of the one- time impact from transitioning to the new ERP system in F3/26, we now believe losses will still continue into F3/27 due to demand weakening more than we expected.

Grohe: Both sales and the business profit margin are solid despite housing market demand remaining weak in the core German housing market and elsewhere, thanks to the resumption of procurement by customers, a boost from new products (including a boost from higher production capacity utilization), and a better sales mix resulting from strong sales of high added- value products (colored faucet fittings). Given this, we hike our BP forecasts.

Full- scale recovery in demand in Germany and elsewhere will be key to further improvement in Grohe's BP, so we will be monitoring demand trends closely going forward (we assume demand will recover in earnest from F3/27).

(2) LHT: We lower our BP forecast for F3/26 mainly due to cutting our forecast for the International business, but we raise our BP forecasts for F3/27 onwards to factor in the positive effect from withdrawing from the ceramic siding business. The company plans to withdraw from this business at the end of 2026. The business has fallen into the red, so its sale should contribute positively to earnings in F3/27.
Our forecasts for the Living segment are unchanged.

Grohe firm but ASB still subdued
Key: Historical Stock Performance Current Stock Price Price Target
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research

High dividend yield remains in focus and Grohe is healthier than expected, but we see few grounds to up exposure due to 1) the US bath tub business sale not taking effect until F3/27 (sale has completed but the business remains transitionally with LIXIL in F3/26), 2) ongoing ASB weakness and uncertainty over earnings ahead, and 3) little sense of P/E-based undervaluation. Grohe firmness reflects effects of resumed supplier procurement and new products (incl. better line operating rates), and a better mix on brisk sales of value-added offerings (tinted faucets). We will be monitoring demand given the importance of full recovery in markets like Germany to further improvement in Grohe BP.

Stock likely to remain unappealing for both earnings and dividend yield

2Q Japan and China earning were better than we expected, aided domestically by greater effects of processing cost cuts and in China by cost curbs and better sales than we envisaged, although real estate market conditions continued to worsen and competition to stiffen. But while China business secured operating black ink via cost curbs, etc, in 2Q, demand remains subdued and we will be watching effects on profit from 3Q. The dividend yield is lower than LIXIL's, and we think the stock will continue to struggle to find favor from the standpoints of both earnings and dividend yield.

(2) Earnings forecast: We lower our OP forecasts, mostly due to lower assumptions for China and Japan (F3/26 only in Japan), to ¥50.8bn in F3/26 (up 10.4% YoY; previously ¥52.0bn; guidance ¥50.0bn), and ¥56.5bn in F3/27 (up 11.2%; ¥57.0bn).

(1) Japan: We lower our forecasts for F3/26 only, given the stronger-than-expected impact of recalls. We forecast ¥26.9bn for F3/26 (up 20.6% YoY; previously ¥28.2bn), and ¥29.7bn for F3/27 (up 10.4%; no change).

The ¥2.54bn cost for free inspections and repairs related to the bathroom heater-dryer recall in Apr 2025 has already been accounted for in F3/25 results. However, around 300 employees (mainly from manufacturing) are currently handling the recall, which has slowed cost reduction efforts and increased outsourcing expenses, impacting overall performance. The company expects this response to continue through F3/26 2Q, but anticipates that staff will return to regular duties from 3Q, allowing cost reduction effects to normalize.

Due to weaker-than- expected cost reduction impacts, we lower our profit forecast for F3/26. However, since this impact is expected to end within F3/26 and our demand outlook remains unchanged (strong sales of high- value- added products such as hybrid water heaters, air bubble systems, and clothes dryers), we make no change to our OP forecast for F3/27 and beyond.
Considering the impact of the recall on F3/26 earnings, the company plans to carry out fixed cost controls (cost reductions) and we expect to see impacts steadily emerge from 2Q.
(2) China: We lower our OP forecasts, mostly due to lower sales assumptions, to ¥8.4bn for F3/26 (down 16.8% YoY; previously ¥9.0bn) and ¥8.7bn for F3/27 (up 3.6%; ¥9.3bn).

We lower our sales forecast due to weaker-than- expected demand, primarily driven by a sluggish real estate market, despite solid performance in online sales and the positive impact of subsidies. While fixed cost reductions through workforce adjustments and expense cuts, along with the expansion of PF2.0 (modular product) sales, continue to support profitability, we lower our OP forecast to reflect the weaker demand environment

(3) US: We lift our OP forecasts to ¥3.0bn for F3/26 (up 40.8% YoY; previously ¥2.7bn) and ¥5.4bn for F3/27 (up 80.0% YoY; previously ¥5.3bn), and ¥6.8bn for F3/28 (up 25.9%; ¥6.7bn). We factor in higher sales from strong demand for the company's products, and a better-than-expected product mix (mostly in F3/26).

Tariff impacts: Non condensing water heaters are currently produced locally (at the Griffin factory), but condensing water heaters are exported from Japan and thus subject to US tariffs on imports from Japan (in the US the ratio of condensing to non- condensing water heaters is 50/50 on a volume basis and 60/40 on a value basis). In the US, steel, aluminum, and copper used for locally produced non- condensing water heaters are subject to to tariffs.

However, since Rinnai plans to pass- through cost increases to customers, it expects a neutral impact from tariffs. It raised prices for non- condensing water heaters by 3% in May and for non- condensing water heaters by 7% in July. It also plans additional price hikes in Aug and Sep. Currently the price hikes it has carried out for both condensing and non
condensing water heaters are in line with its competitor Navien, so it is not at a disadvantage to Navien in terms of pricing.

(4) Other countries: We lower our forecasts for Indonesia and other regions given the recent earnings, but we lift our forecasts for South Korea and Australia. In South Korea, sales are stronger than expected thanks to higher market share. The company will also launch new products in July and we will be keeping an eye on this impact.

Still expect healthy earnings centered on Japan despite near-term recall impact

The domestic recall response is affecting near-term earnings, but domestic business is also central to our forecast of solid earnings medium term. We see the stock as undervalued with the earnings trend ahead not priced in. The Apr 2025 domestic bathroom heater/dryer recall costs were booked for F3/25 but involvement of \(\sim 300\) mainly manufacturing personnel had other impacts, incl. impeding prime cost reduction. But as these normalize from 3Q we foresee the usual effects of prime cost cuts etc. Soft demand in a weak housing market is hurting China profit more than we foresaw, but efforts to cut fixed costs by adjusting production staff/cutting overheads continue to contribute steadily.

Bull case assumes expectations rise for earnings growth from F3/26 on account of solid demand in Japan/US and strengthening demand in China, and Rinnai also attracts more attention as an ESG name. Our ¥5,800 fair value is based on F3/26 EPS of ¥261.1 and P/E of 22.3x, the monthly avg. F3/18- 26 1Q (Apr 2017- Jun 2025; excl. outliers) plus one standard deviation.

We envisage rising expectations of earnings growth centered on Japan/US, and a run of new profit peaks from F3/26. Our ¥4,900 PT is based on our F3/26e EPS of ¥248.5 and P/E of 19.7x, the monthly avg. for F3/18- 26 1Q (Apr 2017- Jun 2025; excl. outliers).

Here, concerns increase about earnings worsening due to subdued demand in Japan, the US and China. Our ¥2,700 fair value is based on F3/26 EPS of ¥166.8 and P/E of 16.2x, which is the average monthly P/E for F3/23 3Q- F3/24 2Q (Oct 2022- Sep 2023; excluding outliers), when concerns over inventory adjustments drove fears of an earnings shortfall.

1) Rising expectations of earnings growth from F3/25 centered on Japan and the US, and of profit remaining at a high level in China. 
2) Increasing interest in the stock as an ESG name due to rising sales of Eco One hot water supply/heating systems.
